docs.text: Go Language Learning Repository ¶ Welcome! This repository is a personal journey through the foundations of the Go programming language, organized for easy exploration. Project Structure ¶ Go_Foundations/ 01_Basics/ main.go # Basic syntax and Hello World 02_Constants_and_Types/ main.go # Constants, types, and variables 03_Control_Structures/ main.go # If, for, switch, etc. 04_Functions/ main.go # Functions and parameters 05_Slices_and_Arrays/ main.go # Slices, arrays, and operations 06_Maps/ main.go # Maps and key-value usage 07_Structs/ main.go # Structs and basic OOP projects/ arithmetic.go # Arithmetic operations even.go # Even number checker hello.go # Custom Hello World quiz.go # Simple quiz app vote.go # Voting logic example ... # More small projects and experiments docs/ advice.md # Learning advice and tips roadmap.md # Suggested learning path Key Highlights ¶ Go_Foundations/ : Step-by-step folders for each major Go topic, each with a focused main.go . projects/ : Contains practical mini-projects and exercises. This is the best place to review my applied learning and coding style. docs/ : Advice and roadmap for my learning process. How to Run ¶ Make sure you have Go installed (recommended: Go 1.20+). To run any example: cd Go_Foundations/01_Basics go run main.go Or for a project: cd Go_Foundations/projects go run quiz.go About ¶ Created and maintained by Njoxpy .

docs.text: Golang ¶ start with golang tour https://go.dev/tour/welcome/1 for api development use the alex edwards api dev side. NOTE ¶ Dedicate 1 hour to 2 hours a day.type everthing. Disable copilot or any AI stuffs unless you want them to teach you or explain further.Here’s a more documentation-style version of your text: Golang Learning Guide ¶ Getting Started ¶ Complete the Go Tour : https://go.dev/tour/welcome/1 Provides a comprehensive introduction to Go’s basics and core concepts. For API Development , follow Alex Edwards’ Go API development tutorials . Focuses on practical, real-world API building in Go. Recommended Practices ¶ Daily Practice: Allocate 1–2 hours each day to coding exercises. Manual Typing: Type all code manually to reinforce learning and retention. AI Tools: Disable Copilot or other AI assistants unless used explicitly for explanations or clarifications. python3 - m venv venv # Activate the virtual environment source venv / bin / activate

docs.title: Recommended Practices

docs.text:
Basic Types in Go ¶ Go provides a set of basic types that are commonly used in programs: Boolean: bool Strings: string Signed integers: int , int8 , int16 , int32 , int64 Unsigned integers: uint , uint8 , uint16 , uint32 , uint64 , uintptr Aliases: byte → alias for uint8 rune → alias for int32 (represents a Unicode code point) Floating-point numbers: float32 , float64 Complex numbers: complex64 , complex128 The following example demonstrates variables of various types. It also shows how variable declarations can be grouped together in a block, similar to how imports are grouped. Note: The types int , uint , and uintptr are typically 32 bits on 32-bit systems and 64 bits on 64-bit systems. Use int for general-purpose integers unless you have a specific reason to choose a fixed-size or unsigned integer. package main import ( "fmt" "math/cmplx" ) var ( ToBe bool = false MaxInt uint64 = 1 << 64 - 1 z complex128 = cmplx . Sqrt ( - 5 + 12i ) ) func main () { fmt . Printf ( "Type: %T Value: %v
" , ToBe , ToBe ) fmt . Printf ( "Type: %T Value: %v
" , MaxInt , MaxInt ) fmt . Printf ( "Type: %T Value: %v
" , z , z ) } Output example: Type : bool Value : false Type : uint64 Value : 18446744073709551615 Type : complex128 Value : ( 2 + 3 i )
docs.title: Docs

docs.text:
Go provides a set of basic types that are commonly used in programs: Boolean: bool Strings: string Signed integers: int , int8 , int16 , int32 , int64 Unsigned integers: uint , uint8 , uint16 , uint32 , uint64 , uintptr Aliases: byte → alias for uint8 rune → alias for int32 (represents a Unicode code point) Floating-point numbers: float32 , float64 Complex numbers: complex64 , complex128 The following example demonstrates variables of various types. It also shows how variable declarations can be grouped together in a block, similar to how imports are grouped. Note: The types int , uint , and uintptr are typically 32 bits on 32-bit systems and 64 bits on 64-bit systems. Use int for general-purpose integers unless you have a specific reason to choose a fixed-size or unsigned integer. package main import ( "fmt" "math/cmplx" ) var ( ToBe bool = false MaxInt uint64 = 1 << 64 - 1 z complex128 = cmplx . Sqrt ( - 5 + 12i ) ) func main () { fmt . Printf ( "Type: %T Value: %v
" , ToBe , ToBe ) fmt . Printf ( "Type: %T Value: %v
" , MaxInt , MaxInt ) fmt . Printf ( "Type: %T Value: %v
" , z , z ) } Output example: Type : bool Value : false Type : uint64 Value : 18446744073709551615 Type : complex128 Value : ( 2 + 3 i )
